unnormalised: Dr. Kavita Sharma, a senior gynecologist at AIIMS, Delhi, has stirred quite the biryani pot (pun intended!) with her recent comments on late-night pregnancy cravings. In a press briefing held on 16/08/2024 at 11:00 AM IST, she quipped, “Pregnant women and midnight snacks? It’s a tale as old as time, folks. Or, you know, at least as old as the first trimester!”
normalised: Doctor Kavita Sharma, a senior gynecologist at A-I-I-M-S, Delhi, has stirred quite the biryani pot (pun intended!) with her recent comments on late-night pregnancy cravings. In a press briefing held on sixteenth august two thousand and twenty four at eleven zero zero A-M I-S-T, she quipped, “Pregnant women and midnight snacks? It’s a tale as old as time, folks. Or, you know, at least as old as the first trimester!”

unnormalised: Apparently, according to Dr. Sharma, whose qualifications include an MBBS, MD in Obstetrics & Gynecology, the spike in demand for 2 AM samosas isn't just a wives' tale. "It's hormonal chaos, my friends! Progesterone's having a party, estrogen's feeling left out, and your taste buds? Well, they're throwing a full-blown Bollywood dance number, demanding butter chicken and gulab jamun."
normalised: Apparently, according to Doctor Sharma, whose qualifications include an M-B-B-S, M-D in Obstetrics and Gynecology, the spike in demand for two A-M samosas isn't just a wives' tale. "It's hormonal chaos, my friends! Progesterone's having a party, estrogen's feeling left out, and your taste buds? Well, they're throwing a full-blown Bollywood dance number, demanding butter chicken and gulab jamun."

unnormalised: The briefing came after a study published in the 'Indian Journal of Medical Research' revealed that approximately 85% of pregnant women in urban India experience intense food cravings, especially during odd hours. "Odd hours? Try ridiculously odd hours! We're talking 3:30 AM cheese burst pizzas, people," Dr. Sharma joked, sending a ripple of laughter through the room.
normalised: The briefing came after a study published in the 'Indian Journal of Medical Research' revealed that approximately eighty five percent of pregnant women in urban India experience intense food cravings, especially during odd hours. "Odd hours? Try ridiculously odd hours! We're talking three thirty A-M cheese burst pizzas, people," Doctor Sharma joked, sending a ripple of laughter through the room.

unnormalised: But it wasn't all fun and games. Dr. Sharma also stressed the importance of maintaining a balanced diet, even when those cravings hit. "Sure, indulge a little. A slice of rasmalai won't hurt. But don't make it a nightly affair. We don't want any gestational diabetes monsters lurking under the bed! Think of the blood sugar levels, people, blood sugar levels!"
normalised: But it wasn't all fun and games. Doctor Sharma also stressed the importance of maintaining a balanced diet, even when those cravings hit. "Sure, indulge a little. A slice of rasmalai won't hurt. But don't make it a nightly affair. We don't want any gestational diabetes monsters lurking under the bed! Think of the blood sugar levels, people, blood sugar levels!"

unnormalised: When asked about the strangest craving she'd ever encountered, Dr. Sharma raised an eyebrow. "Oh, I've heard it all. One patient craved coal. Yes, coal! Another wanted pickle juice mixed with mango lassi. I'm not even kidding! I’m pretty sure that pregnant women are the reason chaat walas are billionaires. My advise? Don’t Google the nutritional value of some of the concoctions people are eating at 2 AM.. trust me."
normalised: When asked about the strangest craving she'd ever encountered, Doctor Sharma raised an eyebrow. "Oh, I've heard it all. One patient craved coal. Yes, coal! Another wanted pickle juice mixed with mango lassi. I'm not even kidding! I’m pretty sure that pregnant women are the reason chaat walas are billionaires. My advice? Don’t Google the nutritional value of some of the concoctions people are eating at two A-M.. trust me."

unnormalised: She further added, "Look, pregnancy is a rollercoaster, a hormonal hurricane, a culinary circus! But it’s also a beautiful journey. So, laugh a little, cry a little, and maybe sneak in a midnight jalebi or two. Just blame it on the baby. It works every time!"
normalised: She further added, "Look, pregnancy is a rollercoaster, a hormonal hurricane, a culinary circus! But it’s also a beautiful journey. So, laugh a little, cry a little, and maybe sneak in a midnight jalebi or two. Just blame it on the baby. It works every time!"

unnormalised: In conclusion, Dr. Sharma urged families to support expectant mothers, not just with their cravings, but with proper prenatal care. "Get your check-ups, ladies! Consult your gynecologist. And for heaven's sake, stock up on healthy snacks. Maybe some fruits, some nuts… and perhaps a small stash of chocolate. You know, for emergencies," she winked. The press conference ended with reporters rushing to the nearest sweet shop, presumably on assignment... or perhaps not.
